No success.EDIT:   A fellow in the steam forum named James posted this and it worked!Clear C:/{username}/AppData/Local/T2GP LauncherClear C:/{username}/AppData/Roaming/T2GP LauncherLaunch(Need to have show hidden folders enabled through file explorer options to see AppData)

author: Zael
review: I loved Civ5, and I enjoyed Beyond Earth for it's futuristic setting and the affinities system, so I had high hopes for Civ6.And one by one my hopes are crashing, and the game just keep getting annoying.I won't talk about hyper raged barbarians, or stupid AI, you can look at all the other reviews.Instead, I'll talk about some little things that, if changed, could turn this game into a jewel.1) Builders. The fast build was fun in the first game, but you were always putting out more builders instead of actually buildings or military units, and while they can get their "build limit" upgraded, it's still tedious to keep building them. Workers on Civ5 and CivBE are definitely better.2) Maps. This is probably the WORST FREAKING THING in the game, even worse than AI. You are there, setting map on HUGE, and after two or three turns... YEAH, YOU GUESS IT, YOU HAVE ANOTHER 3 CIV NEAR YOU, AND THEY ARE ALL GOING TO DECLARE WAR ON YOU. What's the point of having HUGE maps if you can't build cities where the hell you want because near you the other civs just keep spamming Settlers? And don't get me started on island types of map: they are my favorite type of map, and I love sending out my navy, but how can I send out my navy if you put me MILES away from the sea? I don't pretend to have my capital just on the sea, but at least to have it near, for a second city. NOT FOR A FIFTH. Map generator is STUPID, the one on Civ5 and CivBE was better.3) Research trees. It was a nice addiction to the game, having two trees and having the way to cut the research time in half. It WAS nice. But hey, you have to work your ass off to made it (as it should be), but the game decides that AI players have ALL the research times halved. Because why not?Am I gonna keep playing this game when I own both Civ5 and CivBE? Yes.Am I gonna keep swearing and raging against this stupid game when I play? Yes.Am I gonna keep telling you all to stay away from this game until they fix it? ♥♥♥♥ YES.EDIT: found out why the maps suck so bad. Small, Medium and Standard are bigger than their Civ5 sizes, Civ5 Large is way bigger than Civ6 Large, AND MOST OF ALL, CIV5 HUGE IS WAAAAAAAAAAAAAY BIGGER THAN CIV6 HUGE. To give you an idea, Civ6 Huge is basically Civ5 Large-sized. Yep. And you have to play in that map with 11 AI players plus up to 24 city-states.Way to go, Firaxis.POST GATHERING STORM EDIT: finally I can say that I'm starting to enjoy this game. Bigger maps, nice events a better AI (still stupid sometimes, but that's ok, it's not bas as it was 2/3 years ago). Rise and Fall and Gathering Storm added a lot of things and fixed even more things so it's getting better. New civs are always welcome, of course, and Civ DLCs aren't disappointing. I kinda wish there were more of them though, and since they're going also with civs like Australia and Canada, I think they finally could add Italy (instead of keeping it "trapped" into Roman Empire).

author: Sebastian Borkalot
review: it ok

author: Viper[.at]
review: Update - so now that you can decline the EULA at start of the Game and the patched Redshell out i give it a go ;)Game crashes after ~150 Turns"Uninstalled Game because of EULA - wants to collect Data even worse than Gxxgle :(In times of GDPR it should be impossible that games like this are still for sale...."

author: Rahko
review: After coming back to this after four years, I gotta say I was positively surprised. They really have fixed some of the major issues and the game is quite enjoyable now. The AI is a lot better and victories are now more balanced (although Science is now the easiest one. On one game I went for Culture Victory from the start, but still ended up winning the Science Victory after seeing that I wasn't fast enough with the Culture and changed my mind at beginning of the last third of the game.). The game was now good enough so I bothered to really dig into all the features of the game, and I gotta say that I now ever prefer this over Civ 5.My only negatives are that the mid-game can get a bit boring for some time, but it gets better towards the enf-game. Also, the DLCs seem rather lacking and expensive. Do note that I don't own any of them, but they have received rather negative reviews, but maybe I'll buy some of them and see for myself.I can really recommend this now.

author: Killer Rabbit
review: "What's for dinner?" my kids asked."I'll pick up some pizza," I responded."When?" they asked."In just one more turn. I promise."6 hours later the lights are off in the rest of the house. I think they gave up and fed themselves cereal. Or maybe my wife packed them up in the car and left to go to her mother's house. I really don't know. I'll go check after this one more turn. Or maybe after the next one.(Seriously, who does that? I only made them wait an hour. I'm not that heartless.)Because the Steam Awards requires an update... a couple thousand turns later, my wife is back home, the kids haven't starved, and I still enjoy playing this game. Civ VI is very deserving of the "Just 5 more minutes" award! If it was up to me, I'd rename it to the "Just 5 more hours" award if I could.

author: footstrong
review: Civ 6 is a great game, but be aware the the AI cheats, which for me is a deal breaker.I don't if AI has an advantage on higher levels, but this :I'm playing on Prince level as Gilgamesh.I'm attacking en enemy capital city with 4 war carts and a warrior, but as I'm attacking the city, 2 enemy horsemen and 2 chariot archers appear in a single turn, in the same city.  This is breaking the rules of the game and ruins any strategy that you've thought up.Just be aware of this before buying.  Plenty of people on forums are complaining about the same thing.  It's a shame, because it really is a good game.

author: rubrchicken
review: This game is very fun and easy to sink hours into—but as of right now, I would not recommend it. The game currently has large unresolved bugs with creating new games and loading saves, where it will just get stuck on "Loading... Please Wait" forever. This happens on multiple computers of mine and tons of people in the forums/discussion are experiencing the same issue. Using the legacy game version used to work, but in the latest update has stopped working.

author: Blumenliebhaber
review: First at all Civilization VI looks very good compared to older Civs. For me it's not important to catch the best graphics in these kind of games. But if you want a good looking game too than Civ VI is a good option. But back to the important stuff the gameplay. With the new district system the developer find a new way to improve the game in a good way. First it's a bit strange compared to older Civs, because now you can't build everything in your city without caring about what you build. The new districts have to build on fields around your city. The same applies for the wonders now. There is also a population limit for the districts. So you have to be more strategical to deside what kind of city you want. I really like that improvement. You can specialize your cities and have to deside carefully. Feels different but in a good way. Same i can say about city-states. There are now city-states that improve your districts and come with different buffs if you hold the most envoys. For example you could build a special field improvement etc. That also makes the city-states more important for you. Well the AI is still not the best, but it's getting better.Another thing that works still good in Civ VI is the way you could win this game. War is not the only option to win. With the district and the city-state system that works in my opinion much better.But there are also a few things i dont like. For example the loadtime of the rounds in late game took very long. I personally like to play on big maps with many countries... There are options to reduce this, but this works in my opinion not very good. I couldn't see much changes here. Well it's still much better compared to Humankind, but still a problem.I'm also not a fan of the most scenarios they bring out. Feels a bit like they rename units, change some mechanics and that's all. I miss scenarios like the world war or future scenario in Civ IV, where they add new units and buildings. I also would like to see more unit options in late game. Everyone runs the same units. I know it wasn't much better in Civ IV and V, but maybe they could change that in VII. On the other hand there are mods too.There are some options to improve you gameplay too. For example you could choose extra mods for your normal gameplay like stronger environmental disasters and many more. That adds another reason to replay.And like always i really love the quotes. What is Civ without them?All in all i can recommand it, if you love the old Civs too. But the "small Dlcs" you should better buy in sale.

author: Woolfe
review: I don't love this game.  I loved 5, I loved 4... I've loved most Civ's that I have played.But this one... Just not feeling it... And I've played it a fair bit.I think my biggest issue is that if you aren't uber aggressive and warlike in the early game you get left behind.Previous CIv's you could play tall or wide and still compete.  You could play defensive or aggressive and still compete.Wonders are more annoying to get, and they don't feel as important anymore. Districts.. just kind of ♥♥♥♥ me.  Also I couldn't select an existing symbol for my religion, I had to use a generic one. I like using the YIn Yang symbol.  But couldn't.Overall I am just sad that I didn't like it.

author: Roger Furlong
review: I've loved the series since the very first game. I played Civ 6 for probably a few hundred hours when it first came out, and aside from the features from 5 they removed, I loved it.Years later, I got the 'complete' 'definitive' whatever on a deep discount. I hadn't played with any of the new features, DLCs, and new civs, and I was enjoying the game. Then I get to the world congress(In like 2 AD, which is ridiculous) and I simply can't play the f-ing game any more. Apparently this has been a glitch since the DLC came out and they just never bothered to fix it. 'You haven't voted on all resolutions.' Well, that was fun.I love 4X strategy games, but the sheer f-ing laziness of a huge company making me probably have to download a MOD that disables a buggy feature of their game just to play the thing is ridiculous. Fix the world congress FFS, you aren't 5 guys in a basement. Another example of why I mostly play indie games now.

author: richard.deem
review: At first, I was very skeptical of the graphics.  Everything looked very "cartoonish." Once I started playing, however, I immediately fell in love.  The graphics actually make the game very playable by not taking too much processing power.  Sometimes 5 and even Beyond Earth became too frustrating to play those larger games with more computer/human players.  The Civ team was very smart in not putting too much effort into the graphics by making sure this is playable on most hardware, even making it simple enough to easily put it on a mobile platform.As for game mechanics, this version introduces a lot and re-introduces what we love about previous versions.  New to the franchise, they brought districts to the map, limited actions for builders, policy card decks, envoys, super enhanced diplomacy, and culture "researching." Then they made sure to include features that I love about previous versions like religion, choosing government, rebels, trade, and natural wonders.  This makes the base game already feel really complete.  It's hard to imagine what they might include in the expansions, other than new civs and maps. Or maybe I'm just blindsighted at how awesome the game already is.For long time Civilization players, this is the game we've always wanted.

author: ancieque greenblock
review: Spyware should not be part of a game.

author: llbennett8
review: As the world started to fall apart from COVID-19, Civ6 came in and saved the day for me. It was great escapism during a difficult time, and I'll be forever grateful to this franchise for that.

author: Machintos Everee
review: It's a fun game until Mahatma Gandhi start to nuke your civilization

author: Cl. Kurtz
review: Good game but Civ 5 is better and way cheaper.

author: tjfalk
review: Just one more turn

author: BluntBoy420
review: I bought this game with the sole purpose of playing with my girlfriend. Shes on a mac and I'm on PC. The thing they don't tell you is they update the game individually for mac and PC so we have different game versions and therefore can't play together. No idea why you would advertise the game as cross platform and all that if this is how you conduct game updates. Overall extremely disappointed. I've been a Civ fan since the beginning but if this is the way they do business I will not be buying another Civ game.

author: D3bs
review: They say expect the worst and hope for the best and this game is somewhere in the middle.  Easy to play and harder to master like all Civ games. The graphics took some getting used to and the launcher is what it is and will continue to cause debate.  I like the districts and pseudo autonomy of the various cities but am not so keen on some of the diplomacy aspects and the religion aspect drives me to distraction but not enough to stop playing.

author: Themadhatter
review: NO, NO, NOOOOOOOO.The game feels still broken after One year of ownership. There are controls glitches, that disable camera movement until the next turn. The AI is just soooo baaad. I can steam roll through every country during the atomic age, without any real opposition. IN ADDITION TO: "Take-Two Interactive Software, Inc." subsidiarie games spyware."The information we collect may include personal information such as your first and/or last name, e-mail address, phone number, photo, mailing address, geolocation, or payment information. In addition, we may collect your age, gender, date of birth, zip code, hardware configuration, console ID, software products played, survey data, purchases, IP address and the systems you have played on. We may combine the information with your personal information and across other computers or devices that you may use."I WILL NEVER BUY A CIV GAME AGAIN

author: Bubbles
review: It pains me to give a negative review to civilization VI, it's also at odds with the fact that I've played over 400 hours. But the game is simply not good enough to deserve a good grade, although it's quite addictive.Here are the main issues:- The first, enormous one, is that the game constantly crashes. It's incredible that paying so much money for this game we're not even getting the bare minimum: a functionning game.- The second, even with new gen PCs, the game is extremely slow when playing on larger than standard maps. That's incredible to me. In Civ IV I only played in immense map modes, impossible to do so here.- The third, middle to late game is very boring, and one needs to really be into optimizing to find some fun after medieval times are passed and borders kind of settle down.- If you go for an expansion game, it does not get boring in middle to late game, but it does get painful having to deal with many many cities. - The fifth, diplomacy is a really really poor experience in this game. It lacks depths, it's repetitive. Every game kind of feels the same in that regard.- One of the reasons why the game is so poor in the middle and late games is that there are no events. So the game completely lacks interactiveness: choosing a religion is just about the bonuses, so is choosing a political system. It does not change much to what will happen to your civ in the long run. It plays into the repetitiveness of the game. Put simply, the game lacks lore dramatically, the difference between democracy and fascism are just different bonuses...For all these reasons, I can't recommend buying the game unless you're a historical CIV fan. But even being one, you will be disappointed.

author: while(1)
review: The inclusion of Red Shell malware in this game will probably lead me to swear off the franchise--which I've been playing faithfully since the original--and encourage others to do the same.Whoever made the decision to bundle spyware in a game that *I purchased* should lose their job. While I hate online tracking via cookies, there's at least an argument: I'm viewing content for free, and tracking cookies are a way for content providers to be paid. But adding tracking malware to a game I've paid for is something else entirely, and I intend to punish Firaxis for it. I really hope others do the same, because I have serious concerns about the direction the gaming industry has been taking over the past decade.Unfettered greed, as we see with the Red Shell software bundled with Civ VI, threatens to ruin this industry. It should not go unpunished.

author: kalomir.alpha
review: Each patch makes the game less and less playable. It is amazing, how such a big title is releasing patches which introduce more issues. Diplomacy is becoming less and less logical by the minute (I've seen Ghandi talking about nukes around 30th turn in Ancient times)I'm aware that writing an AI may be hard, but when You charge 60 euros +5 euro per civ, You should at least try. While I'm a huge Civ fan and still hope for Civ 6 to become amazing, I'm really pissed at the moment on what is happening with the current state of the game. And as well like the others, I'm waiting for a DLC which will at least rework somehow the religion, cause it is boring as hell (Although is some sense it is realistic, as religion is boring IRL)

author: ViperOniiChan
review: I've uninstalled this game two times, and I've got tons of storage, so I usually don't do that.The first time was because the game automatically installed with the game "Redshell" a spyware program that steals your information for ad-targeting.The second, because their new EULA (which, again, you agree to by having the game installed) gives them permission to access every bit of personal information your PC can give them.Both times just happened to be at the same time their big (very expensive) expansion DLC comes out. It's clearly no coincidence that they put this garbage in at the same time the most users have the game installed. It's a disgusting and predatory business practice, and it makes me feel just disappointed. The greed in video game developers today is just sickening.If you really want to buy this game, go buy Civ 5. It's a great game, some say much better than this one, and the best part is, they aren't updating it anymore. It's safe from its own developers.EDIT: It turns out that all the significant patches only go towards the DLC rather than the main game. Remember that really cool mechanic in Civ 5, the World Congress? Really fun and interesting right? Remember how people were complaining that it wasn't in this newer version? Well it's in now! (As long as you have the DLC (Please buy the DLC (Please)))They held an old, beloved game mechanic back and sold it as part of a DLC. Super overpriced by the way, don't forget.I'd like to close off by saying 2K Games is an awful publisher, everything they touch is littered and tainted with egregious monetization, and I discourage anyone and everyone from buying anything with their brand on it from now until they stop taking advantage of their customers.Thank you for reading.

author: Realized
review: Absolute trashcan game. Nowhere near the goodness of Civ V: BNW, and infinitely more frustrating than any other 4X out there.The biggest problem with the game is the AI. I get that Firaxis can't make a good AI, so they let them cheat in order to stay competitive (ignoring happiness, money, and warmongering problems; starting with additionally units; having more army damage than you; and so on), but the AGENDAS thing they added COMPLETELY F UCKING RUIN EVERYTHING.Almost every civ gets pi ssed at you for settling within 25 tiles of them, but the map generation is so trash that you actually spawn within that limit of multiple civs each and every game, even when you set the map size larger and the player count lower, there's a script that mandates civs spawn a certain distance away, meaning all you did was make more land on the outer edges of the map while maintaining the civ density in the center. So, they get pi ssed at you for even existing.THEN they get pi ssed at you for:- Not having a strong Navy in a landlocked environment.- Not having enough cities despite you, as a non-AI, having to deal with issues the AI doesn't.- Not having a strong Army despite being on an Oceanic map.- Being a warmonger even though you never declared a single war (only survived wars declared on you).- Not having a high enough population/city ratio despite being seiged constantly by people with the above issues.- Not being as scientifically advanced despite the constant wars.- Not being cultured enough despite the constant wars.an, my personal favorite,- "Just plain doesn't like you."Like, who the F UCK thought this was an okay system?! It's the worst thing I've EVER SEEN in a 4X. All it does is make ALL the AI in any given match go to war with you multiple times through the match, with almost no penalties to them for doing so (unless you take them out, but then you're REALLY the bad guy of the match, even if the civ you took out was literally Hitler. Imagine if the real world was upset that the Allies won WW2 because it meant squashing a civ.)After all this, there's the dumbing down of the UI and in-depth options, like City Screens and Citizen Management to name a big one.I desperately wanted a BNW equivalent DLC for this game, something that made it good and redeemed it like what happened to Civ V, but that never came.2/10, I want my money back, and an apology from Firaxis for making such trash after the glory of Civ V: BNW------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Optional material:Here's what happened in my first game of Civ 6:> Play with friend, spawn not too far from each other. We think it's luck because in civ V you could spawn on opposite sides of the world.> Within 10 turns meet three other civs within Nuclear Missile distance. We wonder what they did to map generation that allowed for such a high density of civs in one area.> Have Harold declare war on me, despite our friendly relations, because I didn't have a navy in the middle of a Pangaea map (landlocked and impossible to have one). [He was also landlocked, btw, so massive hypocrite there.]> Fend him off with my smol army in a mountain pass because AI is dumb and didn't compute to go around the 3-tile range.> I get called an early warmonger by Cleopatra for this, and she never lets this go.> After the war, Cleo's angry at me because I have a tiny army. Naturally, this means war. [Ah ♥♥♥♥♥, here we go again.]> Survive two wars within 80 turns, and still somehow on top with tech and culture (because I could trade and deal with friend).> Cleo and Harold fall in love over mutual hatred of me. Go to war with other civs in the meantime. Germany starts getting jealous of my shiny things that he doesn't have (even though we were friends for the longest time).> Cleo declares war on me IMMEDIATELY the turn our peace treaty ended.  I decide to squash this warmonger before she gets too big. I'm doing the world a favor, here. She's warred with nearly everyone by now.> I take one city, friend takes another. Big mistake, since now the world hates us for kneecapping her destructive powers. Joint wars are declared on us by Harold, Germany (Barbarossa), and Pericles. We had to stop with Cleo to protect ourselves from the Axis, but she's def out of the game at this point.> The war is beyond easy for my superior tech units, rolling over their pitiful arrow carts in my tanks. Eventually, they saw their 300 units were nothing compared to my 4, and wanted peace. Sure.> Cleo is still mad at me for having a small army, but my face when my now 5 tanks and 4 arty could wipe out her TWO arrow carts in the blink of an eye.> She declares war on me. The AI actually thinks because she had produced up to 12 arrow carts that her military could stand against my <12 tanks and arty. I wipe her military in one turn, and laugh. Afraid of further pi ssing off the other civs (America was nearing Bombers, monkaS) I didn't take any cities, and eventually peace was declared.> Nearing a science victory, Germany and Teddy declare joint war on me because I'm settled too close to them and they're jealous of my shinies still. Teddy was locked behind other civ's borders because that's how the map generation works in this game: peopel are too close to each other to even traverse the area.> Cleo declares war on me. This is, maybe, the 5th time this game she's done this, and for the 5th time I mop the floor with her, as she still only has ARROW CARTS AGAINST MY END-GAME UNITS. I fire my lazars and liquify her carts in a single turn, again, but at this point I was going to win soon and decided to drop...  on her.> Cleo gets nuked back into the stone ag...  er, she was already at the stone age somehow, so I guess she just got nuked.> Despite seeing Egypt get the Japanese treatment, Teddy and Barbarossa evidently wanted a taste of the Fallout life. I obliged, then won a scientific victory shortly afterwards.It was a slow, gruelling, and unbelievably infuriating game, but I was glad it was over. After tweaking some .ini files to see if I could fix the starting spawn distance (didn't work), I tried to play another game with same friend and the SAME ♥♥♥♥♥ happened in that game, just with different civs.

author: Strapster
review: Enjoyed this game right up until get to the "climate accord".  I'm not mad that they added climate issues, cause its clearly a necessary change to the game.  I'm disappointed that it suggests that Nuclear Reactors need to decommissioned to prevent global warming.  It made me wonder how much of the game was just popular misinformation about reality.

author: The Big Red Cheese
review: Edit: A couple of years later, I've revisited the game, and I've got some revisions to make here:I love the game as it is right now.  Two expansions in it's amazing, and I've gotten my money's worth easily.  There are still some goofy bugs, nothing game breaking, but I'd like to see them fixed before I call it a tightly revised game.  That said it disappoints me to say that the next time a Civ game comes out I'm not buying it until all the content is released, and the game is 'done'.  I'm sold on the civ franchise, but playing the first two iterations of the game is like beta testing it for them.  I'm going to wait until civ 7's several years old before buying it, and to Firaxis' credit: with civ 6 I won't be anxious to move on.  For posterity I'm leaving the review I previously wrote down here, approach it as a two year old review:The game, despite its fantastic vision and wonderful components is unplayably broken.  Not from balance, though it is shockingly unbalanced, but because it's an amniotic mess of untested garbage.  I gave the game a try because I heard that after a few patches it was playable, but the past two patches have worsened it significantly.It pains me to say that such an inspiring and beautiful game's not worth it, but the fact is it's so overly ladden with bugs it's not playable.  I've spent hours in the past couple of days trying to literally, LITERALLY get the game to start, because the latest update is causing many people to be unable to access the basic game.With a little TLC this game could be great, but the company making it doesn't care to beta test the game or something.  I feel like I should be getting payed to troubleshoot this game more often than not.Firaxis: have some pride in your workProspective customers reading this review: don't buy this game; if you love the civ series, unfortunately the franchise needs some free market tough love.

author: schekker
review: As a great fan of the Civ franchise (I started with the original one and propably played over a 1000 hours in each of the previous ones), Civ VI is a let down. I've really tried to like it, but the game is just no fun.I like to play on huge maps with huge empires, but the civilizations in Civ6 are so close by that you have no choice but to go to war after 3 or 4 cities. A war you basically cannot lose. And once you have defeated the AI's directly around you, there really is no reason to stop. You have the armies and AI is truly pitiful in its defense. Any other strategy feels like giving yourself a handicap on purpose.If the fights were fun, it might not matter that much, but they are not. Moving your army around is just slow and boring. No fun at all.So all games feel alike, with no challenge or sense of accomplishment. Why play?

author: TyruleCastle
review: Excellent game that improves upon civilization 5 in several ways, yet misses some opportunities. The UI and overworld are more vibrantly detailed. Whereas, the leader animations are accompanied by a lackluster backdrop compared to detailed scenery in Civilization V. The science tree, culture tree, and civic cards are a vast improvement upon the previous installment, and allow more flexibility for players to accompany the more volatile environmental changes.Tile placement vastly surpasses the previous installment. The only drawback to the improvements of making tile placement more consequential is the lack of opportunity to build tall. This could easily be resolved by allowing additional layers of tiles over a city when certain conditions, techs, or cultural tenants are met. Though, I do like that expansion is actually encouraged in civilization VI, which makes for a more enjoyable experience, where, conversely building tall was more encouraged, and expanding was penalized. The music has been completely overhauled from previous installment. The music sets the world stage that better engages the player as they take one more turn. Aside from the lack of ability to build tall, the only other issue this museum theming mechanic. Other than that, and the background of the civilization leader animations, all other aspects are vastly improved. Upgrade to Civ VI if you haven't had the change to play. (Or give it another chance if you could not get over some of the major changes to play style favoring expansionism over building tall.)

author: Klaus
review: Sid Meier's Civilization VI is a masterfully crafted, turn-based strategy game that immerses players in the history and culture of some of the world's most iconic civilizations. From the ancient Egyptians to the modern Americans, players can choose to lead their civilization through the ages, making important decisions that will shape their society and determine its success.One of the things that sets Civilization VI apart from other strategy games is its depth and complexity. There are so many different paths to victory, whether it be through military might, cultural influence, or technological advancement. Each civilization also has unique abilities and units that reflect their real-world counterparts, adding an extra layer of immersion to the game.The graphics and soundtrack in Civilization VI are top-notch, with beautiful landscapes, detailed cities, and a stirring score that perfectly captures the epic scope of the game. The UI is also intuitive and easy to navigate, making it easy to manage your civilization and make important decisions.Another great feature of the game is the multiplayer mode, which allows players to compete against each other in a race for global domination. This adds an extra layer of excitement and replayability to the game.Overall, Sid Meier's Civilization VI is a truly exceptional game that offers endless hours of entertainment and strategic depth. Whether you're a hardcore strategy fan or a newcomer to the genre, this game is a must-play. It's one of the best strategy games of all time.

author: OTIS
review: The game has been out for the better part of a year and it still has massive bugs.The AI is shoddy since it declares war on you in a moment's notice.Worse yet the game seems to cheat.Once I was I was attacked with 5 warriors on the tenth turn.  In ten turns I couldn't turn out more than one warrior. They cost too much to make that fast.  The only way the computer could have gotten them is if they given the units free.Same thing goes with barbarians.  They will send out a scout, once the scout sees you it returns to base.  If it gets back the barbarians will ramp up production and attack.  On the surface it seems like a great system, that the barbarians won't attack until its scout reports on you.  Unfortunately as with all other AIs it will be given free units and easily outnumber you within the first 10 turns.If you like playing a warmongering civ you might be able enjoy this game.  But if you stop making units for moment just to make a simple granary you will be outmatched and surrounded.  And unfortunately this is just the most glaring of several dozen bugs that this game still has.It's a shame too.  With the districts, the customizable governments, the civics tree and so many other features it could have been a great game if they took the time to polish it properly.Unfortunately in its current state I would say save your money and buy Civ V instead.  It is much more polished and refined than Civ VI and I don't see that changing in the forseeable future.

author: phydouse
review: I have played every version of Civilization since they came on floppy disks, and the game has consistently gotten better and better. Civilization VI is, by far, the best iteration of them all.

author: FlanCa
review: Sid did what he does best and re-civ'd the Civ outta Civs! New game play, mechanics, and well... Civs and stuff (don't wanna spoil it too much). Gotta say I love this one, and dare say it's a huge contender for the title of the best in the series.The changes are pretty dense, but easy to roll into after a few epic fail plays. When you get down to it, they really add to that feel of grand strategy, think big and plan ahead. No two cities are the same, nor feel the same, even if you follow a pattern for them. No pre-made scheme will work; you'll need to adapt and evolve with the round, every few turns. Everything is alive, like never before.I've played the hell outta aggressive Civs and laid waste as I haven't in any other Civ, smirking and maniacal laughing all the way. Terrain matters now more than ever, and will be every war's crunch and glory. The hexed grid means that in every battle, you'd better make the most of the spots you can decently use, or pay in blood for it. I do feel like a military mastermind as I lay siege, city by city, and deal with the consequences. THIS is war."Passive" Civs shine too, and well played cultured peace makers and science lovers can be utterly unstoppable. "You can't kill an idea" comes to mind every time I play these.Oh and the multi... Oooh the multiplayer. Sooo muuuch fuuun!Yep. Sid also decided to jump into the let's-get-every-dime-outta-player-pockets DLC train with Civs V and it isn't coming off of it in VI. It actually threw in the whole egg basket, chickens, Old McDonald with farm and ea-ea-oh's.If you wanna play this game, the actual complete game, you'll have to chuck out $60 for the shell game (it feels like a fully featured demo), and another $60 for all the DLCs (and that's just so far to date).Another great one, another love of mine gone down the pay-wall drain... I'm sad now. So sad.

author: donaltotheb
review: The game has been improved a lot by the Australian Summer patch and the Spring patch, it's what the game should have been at release. The AI can defend itself a lot better, plus they are more likely to be fond of you rather than just being upset and denouncing you. Diplomacy is a good bit better than Civ V IMO. The agenda system is an improvement, if your not warring Gorgo or Alexander will dislike you so if you're playing peaceful, starting next to them is a challenge.The game is at the right difficulty now IMO. In my recent Emperor game I was going for a Culture victory but fell a bit behind on Science. When I had Field Cannons and Musketmen, Australia invaded me and took me out with their tanks and Artillery. Not only did they have the more advanced tanks, they are "Army" tanks, not just single tanks.I also tried to go for a Culture victory on Emperor with Kongo, a powerful Cultural Civ, but I was really struggling. Before I used to have good success at Immortal difficulty, but I got took out fairly early on in my 3 Immortal games so far. I feel like i'll have to get a lot better before stepping up.Civ VI base game is a lot more complete than Civ V with all it's expansions. You can found an Empire rather than just going Tradition, founding 4 cities and rushing Rationalism, which was by far the superior way to go in Civ V. I also like that Spies can steal Money from other Civ's and that you can create rebellions in other Civ's cities. The ability to steal Great Works from other Civ's is nice.So overall, having put over 2000 hours into Civ IV and 849 hours into Civ VI, I say I am definitely content with how Civ VI is and like the direction it is going. IMO when it gets all it's expansions it will be superior to Civ V, and who knows, it could even challenge Civ IV.

Cons: - The same I've mentioned below. I think I understand now, why is it a problem to make a production queue which is so important for a game, where you own 10+ cities. It seems that it comes from district planning. Still hope, that there will eb solution to this nonsence.Unfortunately, the game is in very bad state even now after half a year after release. I do not recommend to buy it now even on sale. Pros: - several good ideas,Cons:-AI - it is just not interesting to play with AI. It's stupid,weak and unpredictable. - No production queue, no demographics etc. - Tech and cultural trees are nonsense. Developers know that and every single update they try to make it better, but no result till now. IMO it was a bad idea to divide the tech tree. - All "DLCs" are garbage till today. It's not DLC - they are just expansions with 2 stupid AI nations and scenario. - No World Congress. - Many others. Today CIV VI is an early acces game with no significant advancements for the last 6 months. Very disappointing.

author: stumpysheep
review: I'm posting this because I've just spotted all the negative reviews.I'm old enough to have pre-ordered Civ I in the days when that meant going into a shop, I've played every version and variant since, and I think Civ VI is *deep breath* the best Civ ever.Let me explain why.Civ I is a timeless classic. Civ II and its expansions and forks set a new high bar and showed where Civ could go. Civ III was all about trying new things, but whilst I liked it from the start it really needed the Conquests expansion to bring the new systems together, and even then they were still a bit ropey. Civ IV was, until now, my all time favourite, and the BtS expansion is easily the best Civ expansion pack ever. The depth of strategy and systems, and a slightly fussy interface, mean it's not a great one for first-timers, but the joy of Civ is in understanding how everything works as well as using it. Civ V, however, was dire. The vanilla version was so dumbed down I was completing games in three evenings without really thinking about them, and although the expansions helped a lot it still felt like it belonged more on a console (no offence to console gamers but the reason you invest in a super-fast CPU is for games like Civ).  So, knowing that a lot of Civ V's systems were to be ported to VI, along with the new map and city systems that bear a striking resemblance to Endless Legend, I wasn't sure what to expect, and the hefty price tag on the full fat version almost made it the first version I haven't pre-ordered.However! From the first seconds of the beautiful opening sequence I knew this was going to be something a bit special, possibly even as good as Civ IV. The greatest Civs (I, II, IV, forget the forks) are those where all the systems from the map, through city management, to science, diplomacy, religion and war, all work together. Where they jar against each other (III) you end up being forced into making nonsensical decisions and it breaks the immersion. Civ VI, with some early teething problems, absolutely nails this.The map is the star, and the new strategic fulcrum of the game. Firaxis did well to flatter Endless Legend, and there are other parallels that made me worry this would be too much like it, but this is still very distinctively a Civ game. And some people don't like the cartoony style, but I do because it evokes Civ I, we can agree to differ.The new city building system, also borrowed from Endless Legend, works exactly how it should do. It takes a little while to learn how to exploit it to the maximum, but then if you want something you can master in a couple of playthroughs then Civ isn't the game for you. The science system has thankfully been un-dumbed from Civ V and the structure of the tech tree has some nice nods back to Civs I and II, and the eureka system adds a bit more fun. Religion, one of the better systems in V, has largely been ported from it, and now fits better with the other systems. And culture is a similarly good port, although the culture victory is far too easy (turn if off if you're definitely going for any other victory condition). The two weaker systems were war and diplomacy, but the patches and DLC have done a lot to fix the balancing issues - even though at the moment I'd still rather not start near China (and for those wondering, Ghandi is still a warmongering ****). It's still not 100% perfect, but no system in any Civ game ever was (anyone remember diplomats in Civ I?), the point is that they all work together in a way that only the best Civs manage. So why does it have the edge over Civ IV? Partly because the visuals and sound are beautiful - the main music in the game is the traditional song Hard Times Come Again No More, and I love the way it develops into a crescendo in the late game. And partly because the late game is now worth slogging through - and yes, the cinematic ending and stats have been restored. The new map adds to the fun to be had here, so rather than just rushing towards your choice of world-ending weapon it's actually worth building a balanced force, even if you're not going for a domination victory. And it's also worth building thermonuclear weapons even just to try one and reload just to see the pretty new fireworks.  So as a Civ veteran I'd say ignore the negative reviews. If you're a long time fan who wished Civ V had never happened then you should find all is forgiven. If you're new to the series then just be aware that you're making a long term investment - Civ is supposed to towards the harder end of 4X strategies but it's nowhere near as impenetrable as it seems at first. Take a few games to learn it and keep experimenting until you find a playing style that suits you.Civ VI claims the Civ crown, and reclaims its place as the best 4X ever.
