author: Bugzby
review: New EULA turns the game into spyware.

author: ostapblender
review: This is like, the greatest 4X of all time, so definitely would recommend,Just wait for the sale to get the max bang for a buck!

author: Torq Anvil
review: I have over 1000 hours of playtime with Civ VI, and have been playing Civ games since Civ IV. I've done a lot of modding with IV and V. I work in tech.Unfortunately, Civ VI has been unplayable for me for over 6 months. I started having problems with my prior computer running Windows 10 last fall. In December I bought a brand new Windows 11 PC. I've never gotten past the menu in Civ VI... it always crashes before I even try to start a game. I have the latest GPU driver, Windows is up to date, and I originally installed the game before I had installed any significant software.  I've tried multiple things I've seen online without any luck.I keep hoping that the launcher issue will be fixed, or some solution from Firaxis will resolve the issue.SAD.

author: Ac0mpletemoron
review: I really never write reviews, be it for products or games, but I feel that with over 300 hours in both Civ 6 and Civ 5 I've got enough experience to produce a relavent review. I've tried so hard to love this game from day one. My old computer couldn't run it when it came out, and I bought a new one specifically to play this game. I've loved the civ games ever since 3. So it pains me to give a game I've put so much time into a negative review.Civ 6 just isn't up to par with the past games. Whether it be the maddening AI, the unintuitive tech tree, the cartoony graphics or the lack of quality mods (in comparison with Civ V, though VI has gotten better), it's just a lesser quality game to previous installments. So many useful features are just gone. This game has had 3 years to fix it's glaring issues that were pointed out on day one, and none have ever been truly addressed. The excuse then was "well it took V a while to work out the kinks", but that excuse doesn't fly anymore. I can't reccomend this game, only because you can go and buy a better, more polished civ game for far cheaper WITH all DLC. Do yourself a favor and buy Civ 5 today.

author: DerWizard
review: v.1.1Before we begin, I would like to make a note that this review is not a standing stone - it might change in both depth and final grade because of patches, updates, dlc, etc.I play this game since Civilization 1, and had certain expectations from this game, which unfortunately have not been met... yet. But this is a different story, because for now you want to know why this review goes against a mainstream - why cannot I recommend it?1.	Unfinished / unpolished product. I was afraid of this most, "for this has never happened before, and here we go again..." The game is not only half-finished - in fact, it also misses some key and significant things which ALL previous civilizations had always been proud of, such as:  - NO STEAMWORK - 0 scenarios (all previous games contained some scenarios in vanilla games),  - 0 maps other than computer generated ones, it does not even have a simple Earth map to start with (even Civilization 1 had it). - can rename a religion - which is a bad thing in mp - though cannot rename your country or cities (which is very strange) - no auto work function for builders - no alert button for units - the game makes it clear from the start what future DLC will contain (which in my opinion is an insult to players considering the $ 80 price tag for vanilla game) Of course, many of those things will be fixed by modders sooner or later - but that would be a different game, why should Firaxis get a credit for the things they were lazy to implement on their own in vanilla game?2.	AI. Lots of advertisements pointed out to the improved AI. I have not seen it, for I only see some scripted personalities which predictably react in certain way. In other words, there have been no significant improvement here: - AI still makes similar stupid mistakes as in Civilization 5 - for example, exploring with its own settlers, building cities in illogical places, having no tactics against a player other than sending waves of enemies until being defeated.  - Adding to all that, AI does not know how upgrade its own troops, so you may end up in situations where you see chariots, archers, etc. accompanied by submarines... This might look funny but when it happens over and over the game not only loses immersion but also some logic. - Like in previous games, AI still spams player with useless offers, praises and denounces3.	Multiplayer. I must admit that there is a big improvement here compared to civilization 5; however, it is far from being ideal. Desyncs, crashes happen very often, mp games are still very slow, especially at late game (wait times before player turns are unusually long). Also I do not understand why the game "does not officially support" more than 8 players in multiplayer (you need to manually unlock it) - even though we managed to play with 10 players, the fact that game says it is a bad sign as it only adds to what I said in point 1 about unfinished product.4.           Although the district / Wonders placement is interesting in theory - it has many issues in practice which only make life harder for players (which is especially the case in mp). Thus, when the game starts, you can only guess which tiles might later be useful (where is oil, iron, etc.) - so you start building districts, Wonders, and then in late game you realize that (1) you have no room for new more districts or Wonders (if you play on small islands map, this is a big problem), (2) the above mentioned tiles contained some useful resources which now lost forever. - This would be not a big problem  - (a) If the AI was in same circumstances - but unfortunately AI always know where to build due to scripts, (b) If the resources could be obtained by having Wonders on it, or (c) If the districts or Wonders could be transferred to other tiles. Now, keep in mind that you cannot remove your districts or Wonders, even if try to build it once but in few turns decide to build something else - you will be stuck with cosntruction on this tile forever.  - Unfortunately, all this makes Wonders a bit useless, especially if you play an island game - where every tile might make a difference. So, I think the game will improve if players would be allowed to build Wonders in districts (for example, 1 Wonder per corresponding district) - this would greatly conserve the space on the map and simply make the map look better. - Another problem with Wonders is that sometimes they look weird - I understand some Wonders like Pyramids or Colossus must be built outside of the city but why cannot Eifel Tower, Big Ben, etc. be built in the City Centers, which is the case in real life? Also, why do they need to look bigger than an actual city on the map?There are also some bugs and mp glitches which I do not want to talk about for now - I will give developers an opportunity to fix them, for we know that they know about it - they did test a game after all, am I right?So, at its current stage the game deserves 6.0 out of 10.

author: Papa Penne
review: It might be the fact that my craving for advanced strategy has grown significantly since I first played Civ V all those years ago, and how I'll have little issue sinking dozens of hours into a Total War campaign, or the fact that I've been playing Paradox strategy games non-stop for the past 8 years, but something about Civ 6 feels tactically... vapid.I sunk well over 100 hours in to Civ IV when I bought a collection disc at a big box store in like 2009. It was so much fun learning, exploring, growing an empire, etc. I had no issue again sinking 100+ hours in to Civ V. I loved creating custom scenarios and playing them out, I loved getting huge maps on the work shop and playing far-too-massive games on them. I thought the whole international council and diplomacy mechanic was handled in a pretty refreshing way- I usually mod out/avoid late games in the Civ series, capping technology at the medieval or renaissance era, but Civ V actually convinced me to play into the eras I dreaded from Civ IV a few times, and it was actually pretty fun.Going from the stunning steps forward in Civ V, and noting where systems were lacking, it should have been very easy to make Civ 6 and excellent game, and well, it's very far from that. I've only put in about 12 and a half hours, and tbh about two hours of that was the game running in the background while I did something else. I don't feel the desire to play more, because even if I put the game on a higher difficulty, the challenge won't feel rewarding, because the actual strategic skeleton of the game is so hollow.I mentioned the game seeming vapid earlier, and to expand on that idea I feel like I need to articulate that Civ 6 feels like it has a lot to say, but if you listen it's truthfully saying very little. All of the systems implemented in the game are surface deep. There's no sense of anything growing to be more complex than minor bonuses to your civilization. Religion, like in Civ V, is still a joke- and I'm pretty sure many of the modifiers from it have just been copy/pasted from Civ V to here. This game's AI diplomacy makes Total War's diplomacy look like the UN. Everything is still surface deep, the AI is still extremely erratic and often nonsensical. The civilization series has always prided itself on its diplomatic and peaceful approach options, yet to me these have always been headache inducing considering just how poor the AI is on both a tactical and strategic level. This game is by far no exception.Civ V made late game diplomacy interesting, at the very least, in a system where you vie for international votes in the late game world council, in this game, hoooooooo boy, be prepared to be let down.The world council first convenes when you enter the medieval era. Let that sink in- the UN is established before the chivalric code. Resolutions are passed amongst nations that have never met. You seldom ever get to decide what resolutions there are, either. You're told to vote on for two options for two resolutions, and pick a target for that resolutions. Are you trying to get a diplomatic victory, by the way? You get points for this by picking the resolution that passes in the medieval world congress, which is easy enough because the game often hints at what resolution will pass. BUT you also need to pick the correct target of the resolution, be it a civilization that gets bonuses or hindrance, or one of 30 luxury resources that gets banned. Good luck, ♥♥♥♥♥♥. This can be made easier by having a crap ton of diplomatic points to just sway the world in your favor, but the cost for each vote is exponential, so even this has limited effect.So, to cap off the last section, the UN begins by having every medieval civilization meet up and decide to arbitrarily ban cinnamon, almost unanimously. I get these games aren't meant to be that historic, but having a system this stupid in a game that at least pretends to care about history is just really, really strange.It just feels like every aspect of this game leaves so much to be desired. Above all this game just feels like it lacks tactical challenge and those moments of clarity and learning that make strategy games feel amazing to play.  Nothing about Civ 6 is malignantly bad, but nothing justifies its still high price tag and all of its very overpriced DLC.TL;DR, go buy Civilization V if they ever put it on sale again. It's a much better time sink than this.I will say, though, this game has some fresh-ass main menu music.

author: blkbutterfly
review: With each additional DLC pack the game is getting more unbalanced. I do like the Pirates! and Red Death scenarios. Both are fun in multi-player.But the standard game is becoming increasingly unsuitable to multiplayer. The single player game is where Civ VI shines. Deity (the hardest level) is now increasingly easy to play thanks to the new over powered game modes that do not IMO add much to game play.I do really love the new civs introduced with the New Frontier Pass. Even though they are slightly OP they are fun to play.

author: Frake
review: (There really should be a "maybe" button)   Do not spend more than $20 on this game for ANY reason!     I was hesitant at first and then just bought it at full price because my need for instant gratification wouldn't allow for the patience needed to wait for the game to be discounted ( Seriously, no more than $20 or you'll be dissapointed)....and yes I am dissapointed.  Nearly everything I loved about my favorite CIV game (CIV III) is totally gone.   CIV 4 changed alot but the game was so much of a challenge and had so many different and new ways to go about a victory I ended up falling in love.  CIV 5 kept that tradition of change but still kept me loving the new CIV.   CIV 666 just doesn't do that at all.  What they have managed to do is change EVERYTHING that I had come to like about CIV 3-5 and now we are left with an empty shell of what used to be a great strategy game.  My first thoughts during my first runthrough was the mechanics of it all seem almost like they wanted to make this a mobile app and changed their minds at the last minute.    All that being said, I did end up getting used to it and tollerating the game as a new strategy game, NOT as a new CIV installment, because I don't care what the title says, it isn't. So spend $20 on it and be confident that that is a fair price to pay for a new nation building strategy game that was inspired by the best, but ISN'T a CIV game, just looks like one.

author: ishnu
review: EDIT: There was a huge patch that fixed a lot of the problems talked about in here.EDIT2: Haven't played for a while, and the changed quite a few things so this is outdated. They probably made it better though, at least that's what happens with all civ gamesRight now I would still recommend it to anyone fan of 4x games, but if you are not into this genre, I would suggest trying older titles before making the investment on this one.High difficulty player here, and a long time fan of the series.Probably the strongest release Civ, has most of the basic systems from CiV V complete, and some other things added as well. It's missing the diplomacy win, but honestly it was the weakest and less interesting part of the game on V. And on top of that, has a huge gameplay change; The Districts.First off, lets start with the issues people have.~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~Barbarians.~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~The early game has changed a lot because barbarians are a threat once again. On Civ V they were extremelly weak, they didn't pose a threat at all due to the changes on City mechanics from IV to V (city strenght + bombardment). On older civ games, you had to keep military around because cities didn't have any kind of defenses, a single barbarian could wipe out your civilization if you left your city undefended.On Civ VI we get the middle. Cities have lost a lot of their early game power due to losing city bombardment. Now to get it you need to build walls. Even without it you still have city strenght, which means a single barbarian can't just walk in your capital and end your game.Then we get the new Barbarian AI. Basically right now it's posing a threat to many people that used to only focus on infrastructure back on Civ V. Right now you can't do that, and it's completely fine, the biggest threat on the ancient world was barbarians, and this is what you experience on the few first turns.Even with the Barbarian AI being better, all you have to do is make sure the barbarian scouts don't actually see your cities. If they don't they won't launch a horde of units at your cities. If they do there's ways to stop it as long as you didn't fall for the monument trap. (seriously you don't build the monument until you have at minimum 3 units)~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~AI~~~~~~~~~~~~~This is probably the biggest problem with the game right now, but it's not a new problem. The AI on all Civ games hasn't been espectacular, and it's somewhat expected. Building an AI that can play a game like Civ is extremelly difficult. Even then, there's some problems that have no reason to exist. (Like joint wars still giving you penalties with your ally)What I believe is the biggest problem people have is that they once again playing the game way too much like Civ V. You really need to understand that Civilization has never been a franchise that just copies and pastes things, changes graphics and "new game". They actually make the effort to change the gameplay, and this is one of the reasons as to why there's always a different lead game designer on each iteration.Some tips for the people having trouble making allies: send delegations early, give trade deals early, and help your neighbors. The new AI doesn't like isolationist players, so go out there and make friends.This still doesn't excuse some things, but nothing that can't be fixed.~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~UI~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~Basically the UI has problems, like certain information isn't there on plain sight, like the experience bar for your units is extremelly small, or not actually showing up that certain techs/civics give you certain boosts (you have to hover over them to see them, on past games there was an icon for it) nothing unfixable, but it's kinda annoyingAlso GIVE US BACK THE OPTION TO RENAME CITIES. (there will probably be a patch around december that should fix most of these things.)~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~Religion Game~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~Right now religion is a new victory condition. One big problem I have is that you can immediately lose that victory condition if you are not able to found a religion. You should at the very least be able to take over other civilization religion (by possibly conquering the holy site where it was founded).The other big problem is that Religion units should be able to move on tiles which have military/civilian units from all civilizations unless you are at war with them. Right now, the AI can get a huge amount of faith generation, and just spam a huge amount of missionaries and clog up the mapThe religious combat is kind of dissapointing. There should be more unit types, and not just be a fight over who has most apostles and got the right promotion.Even with all of these problems, it's a big improvement from Civ IV and V religion game.~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~Districts~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~Probably the biggest change the civ franchise has made. Basically, districts are a place you put in the map, near your city, where you put the buildings of a specific type. For example all Scientific buildings go in the Campus, and the district itself gets bonuses from things, like mountains.This means your city no longer is stacked on a single tile, and it spreads on the map. This makes very interesting gameplay changes, and due to the bonuses each district gets vary depending of terrain, you have to plan your cities on advance, and there's more "improvisation" on the game. You no longer go a specific route to win the game, and you have to adapt more.What I dislike about this is just a pet peeve of me. Since cities spread on the map, you lose the feeling of "epicness". What I mean by this is that the game kinda feels more like a city manager more than an empire manager. (which has honestly always been more a city manager more than the other). And all of this makes the world seem smaller.Wonders also work like districts, meaning they take a tile on the map, and are not just another building in the city tile. They also require specific terrain to build them, which means there's more opportunities to get wonders on higher difficulties (which was impossible on previous games).~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~Production~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~Production has become more important with this iteration, because production costs for districts go up over time, and to win science victory you need to make a huge project that takes a lot of production to finish. Once again, I've seen way too many people just focus on growth and science like on Civ V, and then suffering with productions costs.Basically you need to use your industrial zones and plan them well, because they can affect more than 1 city (with the factory and power plant). ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~Final Thoughts~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~So the big question. Is the game worth it?Yes absolutely, but only if you are a 4x "fan" or at least enjoy this genre. If you are new to this, I would recommend waiting for a sale, or get an older one when they are extremelly cheap (they go by like 5 bucks complete).Also I would like to point out, that the game isn't "incomplete" even though I said there's things missing, and also I am not excusing them for not having them done on launch. It's just that game development, and feedback "on house" won't give away all the problems. And there's going to be bugs or certain problems that millions of players will find faster than a couple of playtesters.So if you excuse me, I'll go back to play one more turn...

author: Mrblondezilla
review: So i have not played any of the civilization games before, I got this game some time ago and ever since i have had quite alot of fun. I love the interface the map graphics are quite nice to look at when all of your cities are close together and well developed, the games mechanics work well i have not run into many bugs, i love the customization options available and the different leaders. The only qualm i have is the ai, its pretty bad, it does not have the intelligence or development to stand toe to toe with a player and most are just pushovers, the devs decision was to simply give them cheats and not make them any smarter. overall id give the game an 8.5/10

author: Mike Bee
review: I am thoroughly happy with my purchase. It feels like a streamlined version of Civ 5. Some people are complaining that it's simpler but I don't think that is a bad thing. A lot of overhead removed and the new builders I like better than the old workers. Limited uses is better than late game having 100 random extra units everywhere. Trade routes auto building roads is just another QoL improvement but people are complaining about their skillcap. On that note, you can still manually build roads later in the game so nothing has changed besides improving the trader unit. Graphics style is great to some people while others prefer the old style. I personally like the new one and the interface is definitely improved. I am sure there will be some things later that I notice or miss about an old version but right now, if you are a Civilization fan, I highly recommend.

review: It's a bit mixed. If you play multiplayer, you could have crashes, visual issues, etc. And it's not like they won't fix bugs, but only exploiting style bugs. I really do wish they would fix a lot of the multiplayer bugs instead of just adding more content. I know it's not flashy or exciting to most, BUT, I do think it is needed. With that all said, I really do like this one most out of all the Civ games I have played (1,2,5). I really love the ways workers now work, how merchants make the roads, and all of the changes, I think, were good ones. author: Faust1983
review: In general, it's an above-par game but I must say that the worst part is the mechanics of the acquisition of great people. Spending century after century on the battlefield with glorious victories cannot earn you a great person whereas a timid moron with an encampment constructed at the early stages of the game can earn at least 2-3 great generals in 35-50 turns. Great people being dependent solely on the corresponding type of building construction is completely absurd.This logic may be applied to a great engineer but why should I bolster my construction to get, say a great scientist, a great general or a great merchant for that matter? Age fixation(golden age/dark age) also ruins the game imho, simply because it becomes increasingly difficult to maintain a steady acquisition of age points when you step into the later stages of the game.Dark age is almost inevitable if you're playing in deity difficulty and with dark age come the endless loyalty issues which ultimately ruin everything that you've built up so far.It becomes almost like a tradition for the CIV franchise that AI needs to suck at ridiculous levels.It's beyond easy to challenge 20 nations in deity difficulty, especially in terms of militaristic and commercial competition.This ridiculous 'survive for the first 65 turns and you're good to go' motto should have been completely dismissed long ago but it's still the same even after decades. Alliances are almost futile, militaristic alliances are almost non-existent, it's a game that has numerous incredible premises at the start, but in a very short time frame, it becomes repetitive,dull and relatively easy. The Death Robot is probably the worst idea being posed by the developers, it diminishes the level of realism and depth we are accustomed to see in entire CIV franchise.Last but not least, the maps are small, even huge ones are small, this needs to be a grand strategy game with the ability to handle more than 30-40 nations in one map without cities being founded and stacked one onto another. Finally, we are getting increasingly bored with Suleiman for the Ottoman Empire, he wasn't even the best there was,he simply reigned for 42 years with an iron fist, that's all. Try Mehmet the 2nd or Mustafa Kemal as a 20th century revolutionary figure for Turks. Tomyris was a nice touch but in Turkish history, Tomyris did not have the reputation you attributed to her.Osman the 1st, Mehmet the 2nd, even Emir Timur had been, by far, better than Tomyris and finally, of course, Mustafa Kemal surpasses them all.

author: 💕𝓢𝓱𝓪𝓭𝓸𝔀🐾
review: The tutorial is long, but if you're new to Civilization, or haven't played it in some time  then this is one of the best tutorials ever. Many things have changed. Some you'll like, and some you probably won't, but I won't poison your mind by stating what they are. I'll leave that for you to discover.The interface hasn't really changed much from Civ 5, so there shouldn't be a big issue here. The biggest change here is that there is no longer a  panel. Now you just click the city, and there are individual icons to click, and find the info of that city.Builders, and building roads went through the biggest change here. Again, I'll let you discover this. I don't thinks it's bad, but it is different.You can now stack two units in the same hex, a feature I always thought was lacking. Now your infantry can be supported with tanks, anti-tanks, or anti-air units. This is also good for your weaker builders, and scouts to have some protective escorts while traveling.The bugs are minor, in my opinion, and I feel that patches will clean up most of the annoying ones that are flooding the Steam forum. I myself, haven't experienced any that I can bring up. Just read the Rumor has it that there will be a  for it, and in the game folder, there is an empty Mod folder. So I can't see them putting that there if they weren't going to allow Mods. Even in the game there's a Mod section.I got the  version for the upcoming 4 DLC's. So if they come out at $5.99 - $9.99 per DLC, you'll save some money here. I don't see a substantial sale coming during the Christmas Holidays, so if you're excited to play it, then go ahead and get it if the price tag meets with your approval.Keep on gaming.

author: Sidion
review: TL;DR it's not a bad game, but Civ V is superior. DLC might fix it, but it's not worth playing until then.Why don't we have a "Neutral" recommendation button? We need it for Civ VI, because while this is an acceptable entry into the series, I can't ever see any reason to play it over Civ V.There are a bunch of great new features (Districts make you feel more like you're playing Endless Legend, though that game still does tile based city building better imo), but they're all held back by some really awful design choices, a few bugs, and horrible AI.Pros:The foundation is clearly here. With 2 or 3 big expansions (DLC's bleh), it could easily be a great game.The inspiration system, makes the science and new civic tech trees feel fresh and exciting without feeling overly powerful.Natural wonders feel far better than they did in Civ V (They now tend to give bonuses to tiles around them, making controlling them far more beneficial).Global happiness is no longer a horrible limiter in the mid game.City-States no longer require massive sinks of gold to get small perks, rather you complete quests and are granted envoys who give you bonuses.Cons:Art style is awful compared to Civ V, personal preference obviously, but Civ V was a beautiful game. This feels too cartoony and isn't whimsical enough to warrant it.AI is atrocious. We're talking absolutely worse than Civ V. They'll make wars with you they can't win for no reason, will build cities in horrible spots, build districts poorly, and even get destroyed by barbarians near the start of the game. As someone who played on immortal difficulty in Civ V and really wanted better AI this is quite possibly the most disappointing thing about the whole game.Movement and combat of units is tedious due to how the system of movement has been changed. You will not catch a scout unless they corner themselves. The actual combat hasn't changed, but the changes to movement and how impactful rough terrain can be makes it all so much slower and less engaging.The UI is bad. Menus don't pop up when you click the city, but rather you need to click other buttons while the city is selected to see actual details. There's no game log of any kind so if you miss the fast messages telling you what just happened you'll never see it again. The UI also seems to be hard to directly interact with. The amount of times I try to view a notification only to select the ground beneath said notification is too high.Lastly bugs. There are tons of them. Bugs with the steam overlay, with not being able to name cities, issues with loading saves, and even a strange issue where I kept getting notified stonehenge was built, 300 turns after it'd been built.

review: Great Game, but launcher is currently breaking everything for meI'm running on Linux and tried to bypass the launcher, even that's not working correctlysad

author: Chili Stick
review: Game is awesome, but the 2K launcher is literally making it unplayable. Saying I don't own the game anymore SOMEHOW.

author: grimgary
review: Coming off of Civ 5, there is a lot to like and a bit to dislike.  Since the dislike list is short, I'll start with that.Dislikes : 1) Cartoony rendering.  Civ 5 had a great athstetic which worked brilliantly.  Not sure why there was a choice to make everything look cartoony, it was a slight turn off.2) Fog of War rendering - Neat, but actually kind of annoying.  Just show me the map grayed or darkened would have been fine.3) Simplified UI but...not so:  The tabs for policies/religion and government type was very confusing and was a bit much to take in and figure everything out.   Since it was a trial by fire in a multiplayer game, figuring out what these things were was quite daunting.  The cards and slots for policies is actually kinda pooey.  A simple list of things would have been fine for each category.  Cards dont make it any deeper.4) Armies.  Feel a lot less epic.  Where we would see rows of warriors in Civ 5, now we get a handfull of unepic looking drudges.Likes:1) Love the new victory conditions.  Makes looking out for things, including opportunities much more nail biting.2) Being able to hyper focus on an aspect of your civilization is pretty neat.  As England, I was able to really drive home a maritime monarchy pretty well.3) Envoys makes it much easier to deal with City States, not as much poking and prodding at CS's to get them to be more agreeable to you.4) Traders make the world go 'round.  Building roads along the way makes it a lot less tedious than sending builders.5) Not having to maintain builders.  Other than to keep pumping them out for odd jobs here and there, the fact that workers in the late game don't have to sit idle.  They just do a job.  And no more having to make worker boats.  Yeah, that was an annoyance.6) Districts made the game more interesting.  I very much like this aspect of city building, and it makes you think that in a limited time span, how would this city work best for your empire.7) The aspect of spreading religions is a great addition, sometimes annoyingly so...unless you think you have a bigger god to play.  It's a sneaky way of warfare without having to burn down cities.Overall, in my limited experience with Civ 6 I like it, after playing for so long with Civ 5. I could really have done without the cartoony graphics; which is probably why I stayed away for so long.

author: soapkitchen
review: this game would be really good if civ 5 didnt exist

author: Luciferx369x
review: 2k launcher keeps telling me to re-buy the game even though I already own it. wtf????

author: DKGIN
review: Really expensive with all DLC (And there are many), but no regrets for me considering the time spent on it, and all the white nights and marathons to come, be it alone against the AI in divinity or online with a dozen friends.Probably my favorite game with Europa Universalis IV, but Civ VI is much easier to pick up, explain and introduce to friends who start the game. (The gameplay and the goal of the 2 games have nothing to do, I only compare the difficulty and the learning, i love both of them)And btw, ofc The Civ VI parts being much shorter, we do a lot more for an equivalent time limit. More games, more fun :)Totally a must have on PC.

author: AlexThePsychopath
review: I am not too sure how i feel about Civ VI. I've played many of the games in the civilization series, and have 1500+ hours on civilization v on this account alone.Every time I played Civilization V I would literally play an entire game and spend HOURS in one sitting. The graphics seemed great for the time of release, and even before the release of DLC there was alot of replayability.When Civilization VI came out, I was so excited. I heard that the gameplay was totally different.This is the only game in the Civilization series in which I have never finished an entire game. I know i've only played about 7 hours on this account, but for me, 7 hours was about the time I would spend per game in Civ V!There's so much wrong with this game.Case in point, Diplomacy.A nation will be your best friend on one turn and then declare war on you the next turn. At first I thought this was clever espionage, but nope. Its nearly impossible to win over nations with trade deals. Diplomacy is an utter sh*tstorm. Declarations of friendship are almost meaningless. I can't count how many times my declared friends sneaked attacked me... Diplomacy is truly broken. I didn't buy this game at release just because of this issue when i saw all the thumbs down. However, I figured they would have patched this by now.Adding housing was a mistake.Dear god is this irritating. It's nearly impossible to satisfy your people. You think you've got a handle on things and 20 turns later your city is screaming at you for more housing. You can't add more districts because there is a population threshold and you can't reach that population threshold because you cannot add more districts. It's a never-ending cycle and it gets annoying early on. This was never a problem in Civilization V.There are a few positive aspects of the game that I like.They made the game more realistic and balanced by no longer allowing people to hoarde wonders in a single city. It used to be that whoever had the most production would get all of the good wonder, but i'm glad to see that this has changed. Also, despite what other people say, I actually like the new cartoony graphics. But overall, this game was just a complete let down for me. I couldn't say that I would recommend this game, but I would definitly recommend it's predecessor, Civilization V. Perhaps this game will be improved with future DLC, but I just don't find it enjoyable in it's current state.

author: ultralizer
review: Sid Meier's Civilization in its 6th installment is a gripping, time consuming monstrosity where every new game asks you to decide, plan adapt and strategize. The only down side of this game, apart from the fact you wont see your family and friends for whole days at a time is the riddiculously KI of the computer players. Still - I am hooked!

author: brok3nwir3
review: As always, the Civilization games require purchasing the DLC to get the full experience. That said, Civ6 is a wonderful turn-based strategy game, and a great addition to the franchise. Players of the past Civilization games will notice multiple improvements to the game as they play through Civ6. Likewise, the developers have added depth to a lot of the existing Civilization content. The game feels familiar, while bringing plenty of fun new content and enhanced graphics. I definitely recommend this game for any fans of strategy games.

author: 2KI
review: A good Civilization game, evolved from Civilization V, with great mechanics on a bad implementation.I liked a lot the addition of districts, cards and differentiation of social and science advancement trees. I also welcomed the new religious victory condition (even if it's kinda flawed, will write about it later).On the other hand the new graphic style and the lack of “penalties” for large empires (the game actually forces you to rush creating new cities in your empire, will write about it later) dragged things a bit down for me.So, in detail, the overall mechanics of this new Civilization game are very good, overall positively evolved from Civilization V, but since the game forces you to rush on city building you get a few very bad side effects:Capturing cities feels like a joke, for example you may end up capturing 10 to 15 cities in just a few turns with no real side effect on your empire.For the same reason (too many cities) religious victory condition is a mess, you will see 3~4 priests per city battling (yeah… that is lame) for religious supremacy which is beyond annoying.Again for the same reason it's just easier to colonize to get certain resources rather than initiate trading with other empires or trying to acquire influence over state-cities.To get you the idea,  forget about Civilization V Enrico Dandolo play style, it's just impossible with the current state of the game.Something I was worried about, because so many people pointed that out, was bad AI, but I have to say that in my 2 games AI was quite good, just a bit too aggressive, in everything (e.g. Teddy building a city in a tile between two of my cities, ending up with a oblong, space crippled city or Hojo declaring war just to move through my territory).Finally I have to say that at the moment leaders offer you a little bit of variance only at the very start of the game, middle and ending phases of the game are more or less the same whichever leader you get to play: huge empires, fought at least two or more wars, fairly high in all compartments (science, culture, etc).Would I recommend this game, yes, no doubt about it, but don't get it right now, wait till a few DLC are out (or even better a GOTY edition “final” pack) because there are both “flaws” and lack of diversity at the moment.EDIT: My review for this game is a bit dated and should be totally reviewed now that a few expansions came out, but as I wrote back then... now it's time to buy it and never regret it

author: Nordace
review: "The information we collect may include personal information such as your first and/or last name, e-mail address, phone number, photo, mailing address, geolocation, or payment information. In addition, we may collect your age, gender, date of birth, zip code, hardware configuration, console ID, software products played, survey data, purchases, IP address and the systems you have played on. We may combine the information with your personal information and across other computers or devices that you may use."You know, this amounts to legal identity theft. Yes, the argument is that you have probably given up all this info somewhere else, so what's one more site huh? It -IS- one more site. So why might Firaxis want to know where you live? The stuff you bought online? And does this "checking" worm its way over your IP into other devices on the same router? How else would it "across other computers or devices" It does not even say how! Better not be living with any roommates then!Sure sure, they do atleast say "Hey, you know, that laxative you bought last week, how's that working out for you? Not good huh? Well the game will track "purchases" (read: All purchases?) So... Well we just wanted to let you know that we know. Maybe playing some CIV6 will help?-Love 2K.Am I scaremongering? Probably! If 2K was subject to ID thieves entering wherever all this info is stored and gained access to it? Chilling. Also, I do believe there is a -Legal Difference- To having all this info collected -without- expressed constent. As opposed to "given consent".Also, I know what they tried to do with this game, but Civ 5 was and is to my opinion still the better game of the two.

author: Trolled
review: Civilization 6 is certainly been an entertaining game, and I've been indulging in the game for the past weeks. From going militaristic and conquering civs to going to a diplomatic way and leading in world congress, it is certainly a dynamic game and I've made many strategic moves to attain victories. While it is certainly a great game, there are flaws that has been a little game breaking. (Some flaws are not from base game)1) District & its adjacency bonus (Irreplaceable & Unmovable)2) Trading inconvenience with AIs3i) Flawed diplomacy - World Congress (How is it possible that a bunch of  can meet up to vote for a proposal? As far as I know, telephone was invented in 19 century and I'm able to vote with them a few centuries earlier)3ii) Occupying capital penalty (A penalty that reduces diplomacy favors. It seems a bit strange that the penalty continues after multiple eras)Of course, many of the problems have either been resolved by some mods (Thank you mods) or begrudgingly accepted. But regardless of the flaws, I would recommend buying the base game & the DLCs (Gathering Storm + Rise & Fall), offer or not.

author: ryanroga
review: After years of releasing overpriced, piece meal "expansion" content, I finally gave in when the packs went on sale. What a regret. The game is so badly bugged and broken that it's virtually unplayable. What a waste of money. Perhaps, instead of trying to make a buck on your next do-nothing expansion pack, try to instead focus on fixing problems so the game is actually playable and doesn't crash. I truly expected better form an outfit that has been doing this for so, so many years. What a disappointment.

author: Red
review: Needs balancing, diplomacy is a nightmare.Diplomacy: "The art of dealing with people in a sensitive and tactful way."The ai is neither of these things.Example of ai diplomatic sensitivity.-Your ONE man scout nears yours friends, or not friends (doesn't make a difference) borders. "What the ♥♥♥♥ are you doing with that army man!? Do you plan to invade??? You better tell me!" They'll say.-Your good friend invites you to join them in a war to defeat a common foe.. You accept.. Denounces you for warmongering...........*facepalm*Example of ai diplomatic tactics.-Declares war on you for virtually nothing. Sends army so large you weep. Will 8/10 times acomplish nothing. Have maybe 2 out their 30 unit army get killed by your outdated one man bow man. Offers you their unconditional surrender along with practically everything in their posession."Oh i out tech you, out man you 10 to 1, have them at your borders. But i regret everything, here's all my stuff."next turn."By the way ♥♥♥♥ you" *denounces you*. Showing off that sensitive side one last time.

author: ✧Legendary Angel✧
review: A lot of people compare Civ VI to Civ V the complete edition, which by lengths is unfair. Civ VI is by far better than the base game of Civ V without the expansions. In due, time we’ll all watch this game flourish even more with the introduction of expansions. Civ VI has breath taking graphics in comparison to any other game of this category in my opinion. I’m comparing this to most 4X games such as Endless Legend, Sorcerer King and previous Civ games. I must also compliment the new combat focus, it’s by far one of the most engaging I’ve come across in a long time. The AI feels more balanced and gives a deeper depth to the game, multiplayer is a lot of fun with good friends for playful banter or a more serious approach. Barbarians are as annoying as ever xD and more aggressive than what I remember in my 175 hours of Civ V. As a fan for 4x games, I’m impressed by this game as a whole; there are a lot of positive points in Civ VI. Please don’t let others alter your thinking about a fantastic game.

author: SMGJohn (Communism is our God)
review: When Civilization VI was announced a lot of people including me were very excited for how Firaxis would expand the series, the district systems and such were extremely promising even though we sort of had districts in Civ V already with the great person improvements. When the first few gameplay videos came a massive wave of disappointment was already being announced and when we finally got to play the game we got even more disappointed in how awfully designed the game is. I have 1037 hours in Civilization V and too many thousands to count in Civ IV but Civ VI is just too boring and I will explain why.The district system is an interesting idea do not get me wrong but the fact that they actually made building tall (high population per city) pointless and you can basically spam as many cities as you want unlimited whereas in Civ V you at least had a form of balance to prevent that.In all Civilization games there were rewards and downsides in going tall and wide (lots of cities) whereas in Civ VI the only benefit is going wide and not tall at all.The districts do not help with this either making your low population cities extremely overpowered. all you need is the commercial, industrial and there you go, the harbour if coastal and/or Holy Site or Campus and basically your city wont have to grow any larger because Civ VI is all about money and production, you rule those you own the game.This is the dumbest way of designing a game the fact that production costs SCALE with how much you produce something is even more idiotic. This was their idea of preventing you spamming cities but it turns out its working against you, want to make more infantry and tanks to fight the wars the dumb AI starts all the time? Oh sorry, you already made too many tanks, its 40 turns to make one now. They also completely ruined culture, its pointless now, I cannot tell whether it has an effect on border growth because they completely butchered the interface and dumbed it so much down its counterproductive. The policy idea is also another great idea but poorly implemented, the idea of enacting your own policies is very nice indeed but it basically costs you nothing, everytime you research a culture policy you can to change your government. This is silly so what is the point of culture? Its basically just like science, its only there to make you progress and the theater square is pretty much pointless as you already can amaze good culture output through buildings and religion. Then we get to the real big ugly flaw of this game, the AI itself, its the worst AI I have seen in a strategy game and believe me I play and have played a LOT of strategy games, I seen AI's from 2002 that are smarter than this and that is sad. The AI was very smart in Civilization IV after the final expansion pack, the AI was pretty dumb in Civ V but even then it was still capable of doing SOMETHING. In Civ VI the AI is utterly useless in war, even with mods the AI is so crippled it scares me, it cannot do basic manouvers it just spams units at you which is pretty silly at least in previous Civ games the AI would try to come up with basic tactics. The AI is also really bad at economy and city placement, early games the AI may be ahead of you but then you suddenly start getting ahead of the AI really fast.As for the graphics this is a matter of taste, but I always prefered the more realistic art look of the previous games than this new cartoon look which looks silly in my opinion, are we playing a game for kids now? You may think so considering how dumbed down the game is in general.I have also noticed how Firaxis are releasing lots of small DLC's, seeing how this is going it looks like they have adopted the Paradox Interactive strategy of just spamming lots of tiny DLC's for what may appear like small prices but when you start adding all these tiny DLC's together you suddenly end up with prices like 100 euro or 300 euro, Europa Universalis IV is probably 400 euro by now if you want all the DLC's. This new strategy by game developers is disgusting and frankly puts me off completely from buying their games in the future, it was bad enough with the death of Expansion Packs and the beginning of DLC's but Firaxis still kept making good DLC's for Civ V.And finally, I want to give Firaxis my middle finger, Civilization V is the most successful strategy game of our time so far, and there still more people playing Civ V today than VI, you could have made MORE profits making DLC's for Civ V and expanding the game further, a lot of people may not realise this but the district system could EASILY been implemented in Civ V, you could have fleshed out the future era, you could have made space colonisation a thing, the fact that Civilization Beyond Earth was not made a DLC for Civ V puzzles me.Game developers today are extremely lazy and it seems Firaxis have joined the club, expanding already extremely successfully game franchises with more content is too much effort these days, Firaxis promised us many years ago to fix Multiplayer in Civ V and add mod support what do we get? An entire new game that costs 60 euro at launch, thank you Firaxis for sinking to a level even EA Games have yet to reach.

author: ilalighieri
review: Sid Meier's Civilization VI is the next installation in the Civilization series. I have played all of the Civilization games from Civilization IV until now. Most of the reviews are comparing Civilization VI to V, so that is what I will do, because this is the game that will replace V. VI has many sweeping differences like the visual style, the district system, diplomacy, government types, civic and technology trees, and even different win conditions. These changes bring new methods to playing that users have to adapt to in order to succeed, for example, city planning is major. City planning can make or break your cities in that you cannot just settle near luxury resources and thrive, you need to have locations for districts, and if you're cunning, have good adjacency bonuses too. Wonders also play a major key in city planning, some wonders require that they, for example, are next to a river that is adjacent to a Commercial Hub (type of district). Now all of these changes bring the question, is it any good, and then, is it any better?+Visual style is refreshing for this series+ Districts and wonders require careful city planning+ Difficulty settings are more difficult than before+ Barbarians are relentless and seem more true to life+ Leaders have agendas that fit ingame scenarios and historical ones, too+ Declaring war must have reason, or you are considered a warmongerer+ Fantastic visuals on leader screens (individual hairs and pores!)+ New score is incredible and enticing. (personally, I like it better than Baba Yetu)+ User interface redesign is intuitive and detailed- Game is difficult to get involved in, more so than previous titles- Visual style is comparable to mobile games- Minor bugs and removals that are apparent (may be fixed soon)- Minor spelling errors (no periods, you instead of your, etc)- Some inconsistenties and weird stuff (dialogue when demanding stuff is the same as when trading)Civilization VI is a new title, released on October 21, and is still getting its footing. It has large shoes to fill for its predecessors and will certainly take some time to get everything in order, with bugs and DLC expansions to fix these issues or lackings. Now, the DLCs are still to come and there are minor issues to fix, so this review can't confirm or deny that it will get better, but it is likely. In conclusion, it is worth the full retail price of USD $60.

review: This iteration of Civ tried something new, some people hate it but I love it.  Good game

review: Just like Civilization V, but with some new additions, such as:+ An art style that looks twice as cartoonish as Civ5, yet twice as lifeless!+ Brand new $40 DLC game mechanics, as fleshed out and intrusive as a free mod!+ Districts, the best new game mechanic since Civ4, reigned in by terrible nerfs and horrible build times!+ Globally influential civilizations, like the famous Amanitore of Nubia! No!?)+ A robust and well integrated spyware, free with every purchase!A must have for anyone sick of Civ 5, with a desire for Firaxis watch your every move, and more than $140 bucks to burn!

author: Mat Vega
review: The amount of reviews claiming this game is bad made by people with less then 50 hours in this game is honestly mind-boggling. From someone who has played Civilization 5, Civilization Beyond Earth and Civilization 6, I really enjoy this installment. Whilst there are many things that Civ 5 does better (which from the looks of things, will be fixed in Civ 6 with the upcoming Gathering Storm Expansion), this installment does alot of things great aswell. Golden Ages, Districts, Religion, Cultural Advancements and much more are all done superbly well. Whilst it does falter in some areas, such as the AI (which to be fair, was also not the best in Civ 5) and Diplomacy (which looks to be getting an overhaul with Gathering Storm), it is certainly not as bad as people make it out to be.TLDR, Civilization 6 is actually really good. Get it now.

author: Torrentro
review: So, obviously before i begin i should mention the the dlc's for this game are ridiculous and that i feel a little ripped off for paying the extra 20$ to get the first 4 expansion packs. Regardless of the money its the gameplay that makes or breaks a game so lets get into that. So, is this game worth your money? Short answer, no, Not in its current state. The Ai on anything less than emporer is downright laughable, they will declare war for silly reasons like you having luxury resources they do not, or a smaller navy. I wouldnt necessarily be apposed to this, if they actually did anything with their wars, obviously their tactics leave a little to be desired, but, not only are they unable to capture city's without a significant tech lead on you, they will often lose 2-3 city's in their wars, that THEY declared, they seemingly dont prepare at all, and then YOU will be labeled as the warmonger because they are terrible at wars THEY declared. It is fixable with mods, but no game should get a positive review if it is described as "fixable with mods", so i wouldnt buy until its at a significant discount.

author: Callsign Royal
review: I feel cheated being honest. I paid £50 for this. That's allot of ♥♥♥♥♥♥ money and for a game that's worth less then civ 5. The game is so focussed on it's gimics that it forgot how to be a good civ game. The unit variation is woeful. The tech progression is terrible. You'll find people with tanks fighting against spearmen frequently. It feels like there's nothing here except a few gimics. I honestly would have got a refund but because civ is so long I went over the allowed time. SO now I've wasted £50 on a game i don't like playing. Don't make the same mistake as me. Get civ 5.

author: Gorbatross
review: So far the best installment of the series.Most of the bad reviews are due to major issues at launch which have been fixed, as well as the RedShell spyware which has also been removed.As far as the game, Civ6 adds a ton of depth with several new mechanics, a few major tweaks of old mechanics, and a multitude of minor adjustments and quality of life fixes to the core Civ style.The first and most heavily discussed is the introduction of districts.  Districts are sections of your city that are placed down on physical tiles outside of the city-center tile that gain bonuses depending on the surrounding terrain. For example, commercial hubs gain more gold if they are adjacent to a harbor and/or a river, and industrial zones benefit from mines and quarries.  Developing your cities and planning district placement is always a puzzle to be solved that rewards good strategy and forethought.  Another major addition in 6 is that the tech tree has been split into two: the tech tree and the civics tree.  Technology works the same, but many of the things you might expect from a cultural or civics development is placed in the civics tree.  New government unlocks, religious perks, and the majority of world wonders are unlocked in the civics tree, which you advance through culture rather than science.  The mechanic is done very well, and as a civ veteran i welcome anything that makes science less important!The last major change worth mentioning is the new Great People mechanic.  In Civ6, players compete for great people.  There are only so many classical era Great Generals, so if the other players work hard enough they can deny you great people entirely!  Also, each great person is unique.  Galileo is always a renaissance era great scientist, and he always has the same ability which is unique to him (science gained for each adjacent mountain.)  Whereas Hildegard is a medieval era great scientist and always has his ability (holy sites generate science too.)  This gives a lot of character to what was previously a very boring mechanic.The biggest complaint about the game I have is the pitiful excuse of an AI when playing a comp game.  The computer-controlled civs are even dumber due to the higher complexity of civ6 and rely on even larger starting bonuses and global buffs at higher difficulties to counteract their stupid play habits.  But as anyone who has been a longtime civ player, bad AI has been a hallmark of the series so this is to be expected.Overall, I would recommend Civ6 to anyone who has played and enjoyed previous civ games.  The bad review scores of the game i believe come from a bungled launch (that I wasn't a part of, to be fair) and a knee-jerk reaction from the community.

author: Klefgun
review: I have 300 hours in Civilization V, so I can tell you my general first impressions of this game.1: The districts added to the game seemed to add a sense of depth that was important and very crucial to city building, however it seemed pale in comparison to what it was aiming for. The overall city-building aspect seemed diminished overall because of the sheer power early game has potential for.2. Early game overpowers everything by far. If you don't have about 20 tiles between you and the nearest competitor, one of you can easily get facerolled by the mass production of low-level troops because cities no longer have their ability to attack units within 3 units of their hexagon, meaning that four warriors can just blatantly mass siege a city with little to no penalty for waiting long durations of time, unlike in Civ V where if you fortified and waited outside of an enemy's city, regardless of size, they could retaliate with little attacks to, at the very least, wittle you down, but it was very significant early game.3. AI is terrible, as usual, but this is exceptionally terrible compared to previous Civilization games due to the added depth of the Civil tree and Technology tree, as well as trying to determine when to build districts vs when to build regular improvements via builders, and they seem to only focus roughly 80-90% of their resources on "improving" themselves, but I have personally seen people have Settlers for over 50 turns sitting in a single tile at their city center, but I am not sure if it's because they can't find suitable land to settle a city on or if they are just uncertain of how to settle a city.3.1 AI seems to denounce randomly. If you declare one war and win or take anything of value, it will almost always have a huge penalty for the late game which usually involves every single AI in the game denouncing you and then eventually declaring a massive joint war against you due to "Warmongering." However, typically, they are very unmilitarized so you can defend very well unless you completely abandon all of your cities and leave them completely defenseless.4. The art style has caused a lot of various flak and such, but overall, I didn't mind it too much since I run on a more low-end PC. However, the art style feels very cartoonish, which is not necessarily a bad thing, but it constantly feels like the map is extensively crowded. I cannot exactly pinpoint this issue, because Civilization 5 has moments where it feels more crowded, but something about the icons makes it feel very condensed and unreadable, and I believe it is because you cannot zoom out as much. Not really a huge issue, but still a complaint that didn't help the game overall.5. The separation of the Civics tree and the Technology tree as long as the added addition of the policy cards seem more like a tag-along for "added depth," when in reality they just feel poorly designed overall, more specifically the card system. There are some cards that are overall better in almost every situation, especially early game, and do not harbor any benefits that can be established from the overall diversity of other cards. For example, the first two military card options you are able to choose from are recon units gaining more experience from exploring, or bonus damage against barbarians. Due to the very oppressive presence of barbarians, it is almost never a good idea to choose recon experience over the damage to barbarians. Not only that, but to level up any unit requires a turn where the unit is required to be dormant, meaning you have less time to actually explore, and in the early game where recon units are most impressive, you should always be competing to find tribal villages to jumpstart technologies and gain advantages. You can argue that in the long run, bonus recon exp pays off, but if barbarians have the opportunity to pillage your lands and stunt your growth, late game doesn't matter anymore because you simply don't have one, you're just another city waiting to be plundered at that point. And barbarians can very well utterly obliterate someone at the beginning to hinder their growth dramatically and leave them well open for invasion, and it can be a case of bad RNG from barbarian spawns. This also ties into how hard it is to defend cities early game.Overall, I'd say the separation of the Civics tree and Technology tree wasn't a bad idea, it was indeed a very GOOD idea, but the execution with the addition of cards seems very poor and needs a rework or overhaul, or at least tweaking. Balancing issues are overly abundant with early game civilizations have very obvious advantages due to the ability to mass spam units and faceroll an advantage.I paid $80 for this game, which is part of the reason I am very disappointed. Even if I had just paid the flat $60 for this game alone and not the future DLCs, I would have expected at least some bit of reassurance that my money wasn't entirely wasted due to unreleased content. It was fun in some moments as a relaxing, casual game, but overall, it provided little to no challenge due to the AI difficulties being additional cheats for the AI instead of actual reasoning or tweaks to the situational awareness.Within a few patches, I believe this game will be far more enjoyable, but don't buy it at full price unless you plan on waiting a few additional weeks to months for quality gameplay.

author: Outlaw
review: Seems really great so far. It's like a new game. Forget Civ5, this is more like Civ2. So many various stuff you can do.

author: Zoul
review: Easy way to waste time

author: Chroto
review: Civilization 6 takes the excellent formula of Civilization 5 and builds upon it in a satisfying way. The new city districts system is a whole new level of management and I could not imagine playing Civ without it again. The music, art style, and leader animations all bring this alternate history to life in new and exciting ways. Now, time for the elephant in the room. The AI can act very wonky. They are unpredictable and will do whatever they please regardless of their friendship status with you. I had Rome, my game long ally and friend, declare war on me when I completely outmatched them. Their whole civilization gone because they decided they wanted some bananas. I just wish it would take more into consideration before making a game changing decision like that. Not to mention how their agendas tend to make them act like entitled brats very quickly. Agendas should add to the complexity of diplomacy rather than dictate tantrums because I have one more luxury resource than them. However, considering this is the most launch content any Civ game has ever had, I'm very hopeful these will be ironed out over time. I am so excited to see what the future holds considering we already have what Civ V's major expansions were (no World Congress though). All in all, the game is still extremely addicting and fun to play. It can only get better from here, and they are off to an outstanding start! Now excuse me as I go take one more turn.

author: Afterlife
review: The game itsself is good, but my god they absolutely ruined it with their awful awful launcher. I don't see why game devs like to shoot themselves in the foot just to have their special little launcher. It crashes constantly now, when before i could run giant oversized maps with no issues whatsoever. Please 2k give up on your launcher. Nobody likes it. Nobody wants it. It doesn't do anything to add to the experience. It just ruins it

author: asd_Logan
review: I have always been a huge fan of Civ V, and have tried to repeatedly like this "updated" version, but I don't; I find it frustrating and somewhat tedious.The turn system is annoying, it is difficult to survive, and the constant hassling from AI players isn't for me. I continue to play Civ V while most of the folks I know are playing Civ VI.I wanted to like and recommend this, but I can't.

author: nix413
review: The game has been out for over a year, and yet stupid STUPID bugs like not being able to scroll at the top of the screen or clear/click on notifications on the side of the screen haven't been fixed yet.Could this be a good game? Probably.Are the developers ever going to actually fix the game they put out rather than work on yet another expansion to get more money out of you? Dunno.

author: ロザリンド
review: A game many steps forward from Civ V, but still a couple steps back, Lots more micro (which is a plus, since civ v mid game and beyond were quite boring imo,) but some of it is because of the lack of features such as alert from civ V, nevertheless the new systems in play bring a lot to the table, envoys are a huge addition which you send to city states you meet, the person with the most envoys in a city-state is the Suzerain, whom, if they go to war with any nation, the city state will follow, as well as you can levy the military for 30 turns for a fee which lets you take complete control over the military of that city state. also, you can now discuss with npcs the things they told you not to do in civ v, for example, to stop settling so close to your cities, more diplomatic options overall, and each ai has an agenda and a hidden agenda (agenda is always same, hidden agenda is randomized each game and you can only find out through trial and error or with your diplomat.) when I saw that beyond earth was coming out I thought it'd be the next big thing but i never really got into it, it had some neat innovations but it fell short quite a bit... this however is a true sequel to civ V and I wholly recommend this to anyone who likes the 4x strategy genre.

author: [GoC] Col. Mustard
review: While Sid Meier's Civilization VI has travelled a rocky road since release with respect to bug fixes, missing features and questionable design decisions, the game is still an enjoyable and worthwhile addition to the Civilization series. The game takes risks in introducing us to a whole bunch of new leaders, SimCity style districts, a culture tech tree, a beautiful soundtrack that evolves through the ages and Eureka moments. As Sean Bean says, "One does not simply take one more turn" when you're playing Civilization and this still rings true for Civilization VI.

author: Medivh
review: Great game, it allows for tons of different strategies and a plentitude hours of gameplay, this might also be a slight problem taking into consideration my personal experience with quite lengthy matches, for this reason I doubt I would be capable of participating in an online match. Overall a great game which if you are a fan of strategy you ought to give a try.

author: Endless ∞
review: Civilization VI improves on the earlier games in the series in pretty much every way possible. To conquer the world has never been more fun.10/10

author: liagoutas
review: Very dissapointed and frustrated. After mastering the CIV V and getting this on humble bundle(worst 12$ spent) i realise how good CIV V was and how bad CIV VI truely is. I mean aside from the atrocious art style/cartoon graphics(it is that bad),you get a worst UI than in CIV V and the AI is plain useless/haphazardous/total random(albeit improved a little in latest patch). CIV VI is badly optimized when running in full glory,which is the way it meant to be played. If my high-end PC can barely handle this and i get my CPU temps rising to hell,then the medium/average/casual player will play this on medium settings and get even worse graphics/gameplay. So even if you find the art style "appealing" and you dont care about the UI,you still have to suffer the terrible utter annoying voice acting! Seriously,who the f**k is responsible for this? This game comes from a historic franchise and is hyped as an AAA video game,but in reality it looks worse than its predesessor,plays worse than CIV V and it doesnt live the hype at all.  No wonder why it took  18months,plus sales/humble bundle to reach CIV V in users online(Stats tab on Steam). Proceed at your own risk(you can check everything i say on the DEMO) and definitely not recommended.

author: Cyonis
review: Downvote until EULA is fixed. There's no need for that junk in the gaming world, we already get taken advantage of everywhere we go online and in social media.

author: Kozzy
review: 8 Hours In-Game Impressions From a Civilization vet:- Almost everything is improved, from the ai being slightly better (still needs some work), the game has MUCh more content on launch than Civ 4, Beyond Earth and Civ 5 had during there launches, Sean beans voice is beautiful and a joy to hear, awesome new features (I LOVE the district addition!), The UI is maybe the best it has been and of course the game gives you that classic civilization feeling "Just One More Turn!"- The things I feel like could be improved is the AI (I feel like its improved from the last game but still not on par with say stardock,etc..) and the art design (It is very bright, doesn't bother me as much as I expected but I def feel like I would have liked better art design) and it needs the ability to name you're cities! (Not sure why this was not included lol).Overall I am very impressed, not perfect but it is FULL of content and feels much more complete than civ 4 and civ 5 on release. With a few expansion packs this will, without a doubt be my favorite Civilization game ever (Civ 2 is my fav). Well done devs!I will comeback later for more thoughts when I put more hours in on the game, but so far I am impressed! This is the best Civilization game on launch since Civilization 2.**16 hours on the game now and I am still loving it to bits, best Civ since Civ 2 on launch day, but I have another minor issue, the game won't shutdown properly half the time**

author: Sledge Poteet
review: Civ 6 has lots of cool new mechanics. I like the power of traders and trade routes, though I'm not really a fan of now long it takes them to build roads. Speaking of roads, it's kind of cool that workers now have a number of charges that can be spent to construct an improvement instantaneously, rather than labouriously over a number of turns. However, I do miss their ability to construct roads. In addition, the city districts mechanic means you can really specialise cities. Also R&F's governors offer some useful bonuses for cities that lack in certain areas. On the other hand, some (I would have thought) essential features have been stripped away. For instance, what happened to the city overview screen? On Civ 4 I could F1 to see ALL my cities' size, health, happiness, production, income, etc., etc... I found this almost essential for civ management - losing this is a real blow. There are many other respects where knowledge is kept from the player; for instance, if you're aiming for a cultural victory, there doesn't seem to be any way to predict how man extra tourists one will expect to acquire on a given turn. This can really frustrate late-game decision-making.I've also noticed some irregularities in the tech tree. Last night I constructed a spaceport and launched a satellite without having ever discovered electricity, which I would have thought a pretty essential technology for spaceflight. Perhaps my Romans simply used it without understanding it!Lastly, some civs seem to have really useless bonuses (boni?) to the extent that I can't be bothered playing with them. Norway is garbage, Spain is rubbish. Too bad for those guys, I guess.What else, what else? Warmongering penalties? Oh my god, WHY are there eternal warmongering penalties for capturing and holding cities, even when you are not the aggressor? This effectively ruins the diplomatic side of the game. Ugh.Anyway, I still have a lot of fun playing out my world-domination fantasies. On the whole I still prefer CivIV to CivVI, but this is a very strong contender.

author: blackwolve
review: An engrossing game which builds on the Civilization universe. If you're familiar with previous games you will know roughly what to expect. The addition of governors and more frequent and varied natural disasters is a nice touch (from the expansion gathering storm). Some dynamics have changed since previous versions, you can no longer so easily take over neighbouring cities through culture bombs and annoyingly (but more realistically) when you conquer a city they frequently rebel against you!
